article.title: Iroquoian languages
article.text:
{{Infobox language family
|name = Iroquois
|region = eastern [[North America]]
|familycolor = American
|family      = One of the world's primary [[language family|language families]]
|protoname = [[Proto-Iroquoian language]]
|child1 = ''[[Cherokee language|Cherokee]]''
|child2 = Northern Iroquoian
|iso2 = iro
|iso5 = iro
|glotto = iroq1247
|glottorefname= Iroquoian
|map  = Iroquoian langs.png
|mapcaption = Pre-European contact distribution of the Iroquoian languages.
}}

The '''Iroquoian languages''' are a language family of [[indigenous peoples of the Americas|indigenous peoples of North America]]. They are known for their general lack of [[labial consonant]]s. The Iroquoian languages are [[polysynthetic language|polysynthetic]] and [[head-marking language|head-marking]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mithun|first1=Marianne|title=Grammaticalization and Polysynthesis: Iroquoian|url=http://www.linguistik.fb05.uni-mainz.de/files/2015/01/Abstract_Mithun.pdf|accessdate=June 8, 2015}}</ref>

Today, all surviving Iroquoian languages except [[Cherokee language|Cherokee]] in Oklahoma and [[Mohawk language|Mohawk]] are severely [[Endangered language|endangered]] or critically endangered, with only a few elderly speakers remaining. Cherokee in North Carolina is considered severely endangered.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap&cc2=US|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2017-12-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Iroquoian Languages|url = http://www.languagegeek.com/rotinonhsonni/iroquoian.html|website = www.languagegeek.com|accessdate = 2015-08-09}}</ref>

==Family division==

:Northern Iroquoian
::Lake Iroquoian
:::Iroquois Proper
::::[[Seneca language|Seneca]] <small>(severely endangered)</small>
::::[[Cayuga language|Cayuga]] <small>(severely endangered)</small>
::::[[Onondaga language|Onondaga]] <small>(severely endangered)</small>
::::[[Susquehannock language|Susquehannock]] (†)
::::Mohawk–Oneida
:::::[[Oneida language|Oneida]] <small>(severely endangered)</small>
:::::[[Mohawk language|Mohawk]]
:::Huronian
::::[[Wyandot language|Huron-Wyandot]] (†)
::::[[Petun|Petun (Tobacco)]] (†)
:::Unclear
::::[[Wenrohronon language|Wenrohronon/Wenro]] (†)
::::[[Neutral Huron language|Neutral]] (†)
::::[[Erie language|Erie]] (†)
::::[[Laurentian language|Laurentian]] (†)
::Tuscarora–Nottoway
::::[[Tuscarora language|Tuscarora]] <small>(nearly extinct)</small>
::::[[Nottoway language|Nottoway]] (†)
:Southern Iroquoian
::::[[Cherokee language|Cherokee]]

'''(†)''' — language extinct

Evidence is emerging that what has been called the ''[[Laurentian language|Laurentian]]'' language appears to be more than one dialect or language.{{cn|Ahmmmm=Such a statement ought be rooted in a source|date= November 2016}} Ethnographic and linguistic field work with the Wyandot tribal elders ([[#refBarbeau1960|Barbeau 1960]]) yielded enough documentation for scholars to characterize and classify the Huron and Petun languages.

The  languages of the tribes that constituted the tiny [[Wenrohronon]]{{efn 
 |Historical examination of the Jesuits records suggest ca 1640-42 the Wenro may have had as few as three villages sandwiched between Buffalo & [[Rochester, NY|Rochester]] ([[Niagara River|Niagara]] and [[Genesee River]]s).<ref name="AmHeritageBk">{{cite encyclopedia |year=1961 |encyclopedia=,|location= |id= |title=The American Heritage Book of Indians|author=Editor: Alvin M. Josephy, Jr., by The editors of American Heritage Magazine|editor=pages 188-219|publisher=American Heritage Publishing Co., Inc.|lccn=61-14871}}</ref>
 }}, the powerful Susquehannock and the confederations of the '''[[Neutral Nation]]''' and the '''[[Erie (tribe)|Erie Nation]]''' are very poorly documented.  They are historically grouped together, and geographically the Wenro's range on the eastern end of Lake Erie placed them between the two much larger confederations. To the east of the Wenro, beyond the [[Genesee Gorge]], were the lands of the Iroquois and southeast, beyond the headwaters of the [[Allegheny River]], lay the Susquehannocks.<ref name="AmHeritageBk"/>  The Susquehannocks and Erie were militarily powerful and respected by neighboring tribes.<ref name="AmHeritageBk"/> These groups were called ''Atiwandaronk,'' meaning 'they who understand the language' by the surviving Huron ([[Wyandot people]]). By 1660 all of these peoples but the Susquehannocks and Iroquois were defeated and scattered, migrating to form new tribes or to be adopted into others—the practice of adopting valiant enemies into the tribe was a common cultural tradition of the Iroquoian peoples.<ref name="AmHeritageBk"/>

The group known as the [[Meherrin]] were neighbors to the Tuscarora and the Nottoway ([[#refBinford1967|Binford 1967]]) in the American South and may have spoken an Iroquoian language.  There is not enough data to determine this with certainty.

==External relationships==
Attempts to link the Iroquoian, [[Siouan languages|Siouan]], and [[Caddoan languages|Caddoan]] languages in a [[Macro-Siouan languages|Macro-Siouan]] family are suggestive but remain unproven ([[#refMithun1999|Mithun 1999]]:305).

== Iroquois linguistics and language revitalization ==
As of 2012, a program in Iroquois linguistics at [[Syracuse University]], the ''Certificate in Iroquois Linguistics for Language Learners'', is designed for students and language teachers working in [[language revitalization]].<ref>{{Cite web
| title = Certificate in Iroquois Linguistics for Language Learners
| work = University College
| accessdate = 2012-09-06
| url = http://uc.syr.edu/CIL/
}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web
| last = Gale Courey Toensing
| title = Iroquois Linguistics Certificate at Syracuse University Comes at Important Time for Native Languages
| work = Indian Country Today Media Network
| accessdate = 2012-09-06
| date = 2012-09-02
| url = http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2012/09/02/iroquois-linguistics-certificate-at-syracuse-university-comes-at-important-time-for-native-languages-132152
}}</ref>

[[Six Nations Polytechnic]] in [[Ohsweken, Ontario]] offers Ogwehoweh language Diploma and Degree Programs in [[Mohawk language|Mohawk]] or [[Cayuga language|Cayuga]].<ref>[http://www.snpolytechnic.com Six Nations Polytechnic]</ref>
